homeric-4-s21-103.context: alone in the homestead — [the hero Anchises] who was comely as the
homeric-4-s21-103.full_sentence: But she herself came to the neat-built shelters, and him she found left quite alone in the homestead — the hero Anchises who was comely as the gods.

homeric-14-s0-15.context: I will sing of [Heracles] , the son of Zeus
homeric-14-s0-15.full_sentence: I will sing of Heracles, the son of Zeus and much the mightiest of men on earth.

homeric-16-s0-51.context: Muse, of Castor and Polydeuces, [the Tyndaridae] , who sprang from Olympian
homeric-16-s0-51.full_sentence: Sing, clear-voiced Muse, of Castor and Polydeuces, the Tyndaridae, who sprang from Olympian Zeus.

homeric-32-s0-132.context: the tamer of horses, and [blameless Polydeuces] .
homeric-32-s0-132.full_sentence: Bright-eyed Muses, tell of the Tyndaridae, the Sons of Zeus, glorious children of neat-ankled Leda, Castor the tamer of horses, and blameless Polydeuces.

homeric-32-s0-31.full_sentence: Bright-eyed Muses, tell of the Tyndaridae, the Sons of Zeus, glorious children of neat-ankled Leda, Castor the tamer of horses, and blameless Polydeuces.

homeric-32-s0-100.full_sentence: Bright-eyed Muses, tell of the Tyndaridae, the Sons of Zeus, glorious children of neat-ankled Leda, Castor the tamer of horses, and blameless Polydeuces.
